Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Development of a Fouling Release Coating Formulation
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a novel anti-fouling coating for ship hulls and keels to reduce the environmental impact of current coatings. Although copper has been reported to be effective as an antifouling agent, it is toxic and poisonous to marine organisms and alternatives are sought. The proposed innovation is copper-free, fouling-resistant, and non-biocidal with a life expectancy of five times that of current commercial antifouling coating and will contribute environmentally to the water quality and restoration of rivers, seas, and ocean. It will offer resistance to slime layer formation on ship hulls and keels to reduce drag, subsequently reducing fuel consumption while protecting marine organisms and reducing toxic emissions. This coating could offer an estimated $3.5M/year per ship in cost savings.<br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel fouling-resistance (FR) nanocomposite coating to solve problems of biofouling in the hulls and keels of ships. Current challenges include copper leaching, slime formation, low adhesion, stronger regulations, maintenance costs for the ship hull and keel, costs associated with down time, and high fuel consumption resulting from bioaccumulation. This project will: a)advance the understanding of the required performance for factors such as the contact angle, surface tension of normally and functionalized nanopatterned surfaces; b) outline future studies such as interactions between surface energy, wettability, film thickness, and rheology; and c) determine future characterization needs. Potential outcomes include the reduction of copper leaching below 9 Âµg/cm2 and reduction of copper loading to less than 0.005%.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Surface fouling of marine vessels that are exposed to seawater represent a costly problem for military, commercial and residential boats, and submarines. The accumulation of microorganisms, plants, algae, and barnacles leads to surface corrosion, as well as increased drag as the vessel moves through water, resulting in higher fuel consumption. To overcome this problem, ship hulls are often painted with anti-foul (AF) or Foul Releasing (FR) coatings. Traditionally, these paints contain copper or other biocides that inhibit growth.

Polymer composites have been found to be environmentally friendly-based substitute for copper, diuron, and heavy metal in anti-fouling coatings, which have a short lifespan, are very toxic and have 60% of volatile organic compounds destroying over 45% of marine habitat leading to tightening of environmental regulation.

The I-Corp program was based on customer discovery and work to eliminate the pains of the customers such as, high fuel consumption due to bioaccumulation, anti-foul products that do not work under all operating conditions, short life expectancy and antifouling coating formulations that cannot inhibit the growth of slime for 90 days or more. Contacts were established from the customer segment archetypes and a prototype development grant was achieved to aid in the contribution and development of a proof of concept or minimum value product (MVP).

The outcome of the customer discovery activities includes training which provided the structure in which customer discovery interviews occurred and helped teams conduct customer discovery research more effectively. An initial business model canvas was developed, assumptions were made, and hypothesis was developed. The customer discovery interviews would not have occurred without the NSF I-Corps training. The interviews with market actors were instrumental in uncovering near-term market opportunities narrowing down market segments which led to pivots. 118 interviews were conducted during the program and 48 post programs, and a final business model canvas was generated.

The training put the teams in direct contact with industry partners and market actors. As a result, industry actors gained awareness of and learned about these promising technologies. The team developed an ongoing relationship with a market actor they met during the I-Corps training. The training and its activities bestowed an entrepreneurial confidence in the teams. The team left the training empowered to create a startup company or pursue a strategic partnership with an industry partner.

Our team entered the training with our best guess as to what market actors would be interested in their technology. Yet, through the customer discovery activities mentioned above, the team learned the tropical waters have high antifouling activities, and as vessel moves from the tropics to Mediterranean and Pacific waters antifouling solutions becomes more challenging. The team initially anticipated it would first pursue the Pacific market but found significant market interest in the tropics and Atlantic regions. The team started with a broad market segment of the marine industry before settling down to Handymax ships and its market architypes the team discovered that shipowners/builders of Handymax ships were a better target market. The team pivoted away from shipyards to Handymax shipowners.

Further customer discovery continues to identify other metrics that matter for the revenue model and pricing strategy. This focused on how to reach the customer and sell products, how to Get/Keep/Grow customers, knowledge of lifetime value (LV), customer acquisition cost (CAC), churn rate, and burn rate. The I-Corps experience also provided insights that will help in the identification of future intellectual property, refining the initial commercialization strategy.

The business model has given the team a unique insight into the relationship of the product and its ecosystem; interactions between customers, partners, suppliers, and their vendors, where work and money are in the ecosystem and how it flows.

A small-scale prototype coating formulation was developed as a proof of concept and compared with benchmark of two commercial formulations using the approve portion of the NSF ICorp funds.  The formulation was tested in the Chesapeake River in collaboration with the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Sciences Horn Point Laboratory and met some technical specification such as general roughness factor and superhydrophobicity of polymer composite by customers interviewed during the I-Corp program. The prototype polymer matrix formulation resisted biofouling from various organisms.

Summary of outcomes

 Customer discovery was undertaken during the I-Corps program, with hypothesis developed, business model refined and 166 customer interviews in mostly the marine sector. A proof-of-concept prototype of fouling release coating formulation was developed with scalability activities considered soon. Field test of the formulation was carried out in the Chesapeake River in collaboration with the University of Maryland Center of Environmental Sciences Horn Point Laboratory.


Last Modified: 05/06/2022
Modified by: Jeffery B Klauda
